First, to destroy the real non-lion and pretend to be a lion; second, to test one's own strength; third, to purify the dwelling place; fourth, to let the cubs know the location; fifth, to prevent the herd from being frightened; sixth, to awaken those who are sleeping; seventh, to prevent all careless animals from being careless; eighth, to cause the animals to come and rely on it; ninth, to tame the great fragrant elephants; tenth, to teach the cubs; eleventh, to adorn one's own retinue.

The bodhisattvas at the ten stages are also like this. Although they see the Buddha-nature, they cannot see it clearly. By the power of the Å›Å«raá¹ƒgama-samÄdhi, they can see it clearly.

If someone sees all dharmas as impermanent, without self, without joy, and without purity, and sees that not all dharmas are impermanent, without self, without joy, and without purity, such a person does not see the Buddha-nature.
All refers to birth and death, and not all refers to the Three Jewels.

ÅšrÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas see all dharmas as impermanent, without self, without bliss, and without purity, and also see non-dharmas as impermanent, without self, without bliss, and without purity. For this reason, they do not see the buddha-nature.

Bodhisattvas in the ten abodes see all dharmas as impermanent, without self, without bliss, and without purity, and partially see the permanence, bliss, self, and purity of non-dharmas. For this reason, they see one part out of ten parts.

The buddhas, the world-honored ones, see all dharmas as impermanent, without self, without bliss, and without purity, and see the permanence, bliss, self, and purity of non-dharmas. For this reason, they see the buddha-nature, like observing an Ämalaka fruit in the palm of the hand.

Good man!
It is like the new moon, which although invisible, cannot be said to be nonexistent.

All sentient beings possess these three, which destroy afflictions. Only then can they see. The icchantikas destroy the icchantika nature, and then they can attain the ten powers, the four kinds of fearlessness, great compassion, and the three foundations of mindfulness.
For this reason, I always proclaim that all sentient beings possess Buddha-nature.

The twelve links of dependent arising are equally possessed by all sentient beings, both internally and externally.
What are the twelve?
Past afflictions are called ignorance, and past karma is called formations.
In the present life, the initial conception in the womb is called consciousness.
The five parts of entering the womb, when the four faculties are not yet complete, are called name-and-form.
When the four faculties are complete, but it is not yet called contact, this is called the six sense bases.
Not distinguishing suffering and pleasure is called contact.

Name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling in the present are called old age and death in the future.

Beings in the form realm have no three kinds of feelings, three kinds of contacts, and three kinds of craving, and also have no old age and sickness, and can also be said to be fully endowed with the twelve links.

Because they will definitely attain [nirvana], they are said to be equally endowed with the twelve links of dependent origination.

The buddha-nature is also like this. All beings will definitely attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. Therefore, I say that all beings possess buddha-nature.

There is a grass on the snow mountains called 'patience.' If cows eat it, they produce ghee.

Buddha-nature is both form and not form, neither form nor not form, both characteristics and not characteristics, neither characteristics nor not characteristics, both one and not one, neither one nor not one, neither permanent nor annihilated, neither not permanent nor not annihilated, both existent and nonexistent, neither existent nor nonexistent, both exhausted and not exhausted, neither exhausted nor not exhausted, both cause and effect, neither cause nor effect, both meaning and not meaning, neither meaning nor not meaning, both words and not words, neither words nor not words.

Why is it neither permanent nor annihilated?
Because it has no beginning or end.

Because all sentient beings possess it.

Because it can be seen through skillful means.

Because of the nature of space.

Because one attains the ÅšÅ«raá¹ƒgama SamÄdhi.

Because it is eternal.

Because the effect is determined.

Because it is eternal.

Because it can completely encompass the unobstructed meaning.
What is meant by not meaning?
Because it cannot be spoken.

Because it is ultimately empty.

Because it has a name and reputation.
What is meant by not a syllable?

Because all feelings are severed.

Because they have not yet fully attained the eight kinds of mastery.

Because it does not create or experience.

Because it can serve as the seed for good dharmas.

If there are people who can contemplate and understand the meaning of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra like this, know that such people will see the Buddha-nature.

World-Honored One!

If a bhiká¹£u gives rise to a desirous mind:

Desire for desire means if there are bhiká¹£us who wish to be born in the BrahmÄ Heaven, the MÄra Heaven, the Heaven of Self-Mastery, or as a wheel-turning sage king, or as a ká¹£atriya, householder, or brÄhman, all attaining self-mastery.

What is tranquility?

this is called mental and physical tranquility.ğŸ”½There may be a bhiká¹£u whose body is tranquil but whose mind is not tranquil.

As for the body being tranquil but the mind not being tranquil, there may be a bhiká¹£u who sits in meditation in a quiet place, far from the four assemblies, but whose mind constantly accumulates greed, anger, and delusion. This is called the body being tranquil but the mind not being tranquil.

The mind is tranquil but the body is not means that there may be a bhiká¹£u who associates with the fourfold assembly, kings, and ministers, and eliminates greed, anger, and delusion. This is called the mind being tranquil but the body not being tranquil.

The body and mind are both not tranquil refers to ordinary beings.
Why is this?

Although the body and mind of ordinary beings are tranquil, they are unable to deeply contemplate impermanence, suffering, no-self, and impurity. For this reason, ordinary beings are unable to make the activities of their body, speech, and mind tranquil.
Those of the icchantika class, those who commit the four grave offenses, and those who commit the five heinous crimes, such people are also not called those whose body and mind are both tranquil.
What is diligence?

Those who diligently cultivate concentration and wisdom, their minds are always mindful of the six objects, namely the Buddha, the Dharma, the Saá¹ƒgha, precepts, giving, and the heavens. This is called right mindfulness.

Those who attain liberation praise liberation for the sake of sentient beings, saying that liberation is eternal and unchanging. This is called praising liberation.
Liberation is precisely the unsurpassed great parinirvÄá¹‡a. ParinirvÄá¹‡a means the extinction of the fire of afflictions and bonds.

Because it can block the evil winds and rains of afflictions.

Because it can transcend all fears.

Because the four great violent rivers cannot carry it away.

First, the violent river of desire; second, the violent river of existence; third, the violent river of views; fourth, the violent river of ignorance. Therefore, nirvÄá¹‡a is called an island.
Moreover, nirvÄá¹‡a is called the ultimate refuge.

If a bodhisattva mahÄsattva accomplishes and is endowed with these ten dharmas, although he sees the Buddha-nature, it is not clear.

There are four kinds of illnesses for those who have left the household life, therefore they cannot attain the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.

First, the desire for robes; second, the desire for food; third, the desire for bedding; fourth, the desire for existence. These are called the four evil desires.

There are four excellent medicines for these illnesses of the renunciant that can cure these illnesses, namely, the rag-robe can cure the bhiká¹£u's bad desires for robes, alms-food can break the bad desires for food, sitting under trees can break the bad desires for bedding, and the tranquility of body and mind can break the bhiká¹£u's bad desires for existence.
Using these four medicines to remove these four illnesses is called the holy practice.
Such holy practice can be called having few desires and contentment.
Tranquility has four kinds of bliss.
What are the four?
First, the bliss of leaving the household life; second, the bliss of tranquility; third, the bliss of permanent cessation; fourth, the bliss of ultimate liberation.
Attaining these four kinds of bliss is called tranquility;
being endowed with the four kinds of vigor is called vigor;ğŸ”½being endowed with the four establishments of mindfulness is called right mindfulness;

seeing the four noble truths is called right wisdom;
permanently severing all afflictive bonds is called liberation;
Because it reprimands and explains the faults of all afflictions, it is called praising liberation.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide in and perfect these ten dharmas, although they see the Buddha-nature, it is not clear.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have heard this sÅ«tra and are close to and cultivate it, distancing themselves from all worldly matters, this is called having few desires.
Having gone forth, they do not give rise to regret, this is called contentment.
Having been content, they are close to empty and secluded places and distance themselves from busyness and noise, this is called tranquility.
Those who are not content do not enjoy empty and secluded places. Those who are content always enjoy empty tranquility. In an empty and tranquil place, they always think like this:
'All in the world say I have attained the path and fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡as, but I now truly have not yet attained. How can I now deceive others?
Having had this thought, diligently cultivating the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a path, this is called vigor.
Approaching and cultivating the great nirvÄá¹‡a, this is called right mindfulness.
Following the practices of the heavens, this is called right concentration.
Abiding in this concentration, correctly seeing and knowing, this is called right wisdom.
One who correctly sees and knows is able to attain liberation from the bonds of afflictions, this is called liberation.
The bodhisattvas of the ten abodes praise nirvÄá¹‡a for the sake of sentient beings, this is called praising liberation.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide and perfect these ten dharmas, although they see the Buddha-nature, it is not clear.
Furthermore, good man!

As for having few desires, if there is a bhiká¹£u who dwells in an empty and quiet place, sitting upright without lying down, or dwelling under a tree, or in a charnel ground, or in the open, sitting on the grass wherever it may be, begging for food and eating, being content with whatever he obtains;
Or eating only one meal a day, not eating after the proper time;
Only keeping three robes, rag robes, and felt robes;
This is called few desires.
Having practiced these things, the mind does not give rise to regret, this is called contentment.
Cultivating the samÄdhi of emptiness, this is called tranquility.

Focusing the mind to contemplate the TathÄgata's permanence, constancy, and changelessness, this is called right mindfulness.
Cultivating the eight liberations, this is called right concentration.
Attaining the four unobstructed [abilities], this is called right wisdom.
Far from the seven contaminants, this is called liberation.
Praising nirvÄá¹‡a as being free from the ten characteristics is called praising liberation.
The ten characteristics are birth, old age, sickness, death, form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and impermanence.
Being far from the ten characteristics is called great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
These are called the ten dharmas by which the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, though seeing the Buddha-nature, is not clear about it.

For the sake of much desire, one becomes close to kings, ministers, elders, ká¹£atriyas, brahmins, vaiÅ›yas, and Å›Å«dras, proclaiming oneself to have attained the fruit of stream-entry up to the fruit of arhatship;

Though one is not yet able to destroy the afflictions of the bonds, one is able to be the same as the TathÄgata's conduct, this is called contentment.
Good man!

Good man!
This is called bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abiding in ten dharmas. Although they see the Buddha-nature, it is not clear.
Good man!
As you say, why is it that bodhisattvas in the ten abodes, because of what eye, although they see the Buddha-nature, it is not clear?

If there are good men and good women who wish to see the TathÄgata, they should cultivate the twelve divisions of the scriptures, uphold, recite, copy, and explain them.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Siá¹ƒha-ghoá¹£a said:
World-Honored One!

If one sees the Bodhisattva at the time of his birth, taking ten steps in each of the ten directions, the great generals of the ghosts Mani and Phana holding banners and canopies, shaking immeasurable and boundless worlds, the golden light shining brightly filling the sky, the dragon kings Nanda and Upananda bathing the Bodhisattva's body with their spiritual powers, the celestial images welcoming and paying homage, the sage Asita joining his palms in respect.

After six years of ascetic practice, he gained nothing, and then said:

Not liberating sentient beings, not because they cannot liberate them, this is called the middle way.
Not everything is accomplished, nor is it not accomplished, this is called the middle way.
Whatever is spoken, one does not call oneself a teacher, nor does one call oneself a disciple, this is called the middle way.
Speaking without seeking gain, not because one does not attain the fruit, this is called the middle way.
Correct speech, true speech, timely speech, and truthful speech, words that are not uttered in vain, are the most subtle and supreme.
Such dharmas are called what is seen and heard.
